content: The Act titled "Emergency Immigration Workload Reduction and Homeland Security Enhancement Act of 2003" includes a table of contents outlining its provisions. The "Emergency Immigration Workload Reduction and Homeland Security Enhancement Act of 2003" includes provisions such as temporary suspension of visa programs, restrictions on nonimmigrant visas, waivers for temporary suspensions, and funding for detention and removal assistance by State and local law enforcement agencies. If any provision is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. The Act takes effect in each local time zone on the first Sunday that occurs. The Act includes provisions like visa program suspension and funding for detention assistance. If a provision is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected. The Act takes effect in each local time zone on the first Sunday occurring two weeks after enactment. The Congress emphasizes the importance of the Directorate of Border and Transportation Security in carrying out immigration enforcement responsibilities. Certain immigration programs may need to be temporarily suspended to ensure national security interests are not compromised. Certifications from the Secretary of Homeland Security are required for the effective transfer of immigration enforcement functions to the Directorate. Additionally, there is a temporary suspension of the Visa Waiver Program. The temporary suspension of various immigration programs, including the Visa Waiver Program, adjustment of status, renewals of Temporary Protected Status, and certain immigrant visa programs, is mandated to ensure national security interests are protected. This suspension includes halting the admission of aliens, adjustment of alien status, extension of designations, and acceptance of applications related to these programs. The suspension of family-sponsored immigrant visas for siblings, sons, daughters, and unmarried sons and daughters of permanent resident aliens is mandated under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act suspends the admission of certain aliens as immigrants, including children of lawful permanent residents and diversity immigrants. This suspension also affects the acceptance of petitions for classification under the Act. The Immigration and Nationality Act suspends immigrant visa allocations, including the acceptance of petitions for classification under section 204 of the Act. SEC. 7. RESTRICTION OF NONIMMIGRANT VISAS FOR NATIONALS OF COUNTRIES DENYING OR DELAYING ACCEPTANCE OF ALIENS. The Secretary of Homeland Security will create a public listing of aliens with final removal orders but no significant likelihood of removal due to countries refusing or delaying acceptance. If 24 or more citizens of a foreign state are on the list, that state will be considered as denying or unreasonably delaying acceptance, leading to visa restrictions. The Secretary of Homeland Security will notify the Secretary of State to discontinue nonimmigrant visa issuance to citizens of a foreign state with visa restrictions, which will sunset in accordance with section 9. SEC. 8 allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to waive certain sections on a case-by-case basis or for designated classes of applicants, with concurrence from the Secretary of State. The waiver authority can be delegated to the Secretary of State for certain applicants. The specified sections will expire one week after the Secretary of Homeland Security certifies to Congress that certain conditions are met, including the full operational status of entry and exit data systems, machine-readable visas, and the capability to detain and remove individuals. The Department of Homeland Security must certify certain conditions, including operational entry and exit data systems, machine-readable visas, and detainment capabilities, before specified sections expire. This includes the ability to detain and remove aliens described in section 237(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Adequate federal funds are available for reimbursement of verified claims, and the data system for alien registration must be fully compliant with integration and interoperability standards. The Department of Homeland Security must ensure compliance with integration and interoperability standards for entry and exit data systems, visa processing, and detainment capabilities. This includes timely registration of aliens and random audits of backlogs. The Department of Homeland Security must ensure compliance with integration and interoperability standards for entry and exit data systems, visa processing, and detainment capabilities. A program for random audits of backlogs of applications for changes in immigration status by aliens in the US must be implemented within 5 days of submission. The audit program should indicate that fraud or false statements in approved applications are no more than 3%. The foreign student monitoring system must be fully operational for certified educational institutions receiving nonimmigrant students. The Entry Reform Act of 2002 is operational, ensuring that educational institutions certified to receive nonimmigrant students do not admit aliens in violation of the law. The number of aliens removed from the US must be at least 25% higher than the previous year for four months before certification. All required reports, plans, and operational transfers under the Homeland Security Act of 2002 have been successfully completed. The backlog of immigration benefit applications has been eliminated. The backlog of immigration benefit applications has been eliminated, and all required reports and plans have been successfully completed. Process changes required by the American Competitiveness Act have been implemented. SEC. 10. SUSPENSION OF NONIMMIGRANT VISAS. The Secretary of State's authority to issue nonimmigrant visas and the Secretary of Homeland Security's authority to admit nonimmigrant aliens into the United States are suspended. This includes the suspension of acceptance for filing of nonimmigrant visa applications and applications for admission. The Secretary of Homeland Security may waive these suspensions under certain conditions, including the repeal of certain provisions of the Immigration and Nationality Act and mandatory personal interviews for admission. Verification by the Secretary and the Secretary of State is required for each alien admitted on a nonimmigrant visa. Aliens admitted to the United States under section 217 of the Immigration and Nationality Act must have a personal interview with a consular officer before receiving a nonimmigrant visa. A waiver granted under certain conditions does not apply to aliens barred from receiving nonimmigrant visas under section 7(a)(2). SEC. 11. TEMPORARY FUNDING FOR DETENTION AND REMOVAL ASSISTANCE BY STATE AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES. The Secretary of Homeland Security will reimburse law enforcement agencies for emergency medical care, housing, and transportation of detained aliens if certain conditions are met, including transfer to Federal custody and a determination of removability.
